This is why I moved the knight out. So bishop could guard the main diagonal. If knight moves, then bishop has a direct line at the g7 pawn and can threaten the rook.

The a6 pawn moves gives me an idea, ...
The a6 pawn moves gives me an idea, ...
... but first I will have to move my queen into position.
Knight moves forward to threaten bishop supporting my knight. But this is when I get to play out the idea I formed a moment ago.

Queen sacrifice! If bxa6 then I follow with Nxc6!+ forking Black's king and queen. I would then be up two pawns, have removed the pawns guarding Black's king, and have my knight ready for its next attack.

I guess Black decides to do his own knight fork. I expected Black to move the queen to protect the c6 pawn or take my queen with the b pawn. But by moving his knight to fork my rooks, black leaves his queen undefended!
So with my queen still alive and the c6 pawn vulnerable I now have a chance to do an even more devastating attack. I just have to move my queen to where the b pawn is pinned!
Black goes for the rook. That's two moves in a row where Black is not responding to a major threat to his king and queen!
